column3: the town's history goes back almost 1000 years when it was part of a medieval trade route. The Museum of Folk Architecture as well as the refurbished Sanok Castle and Old Town are popular points of interest. The region also features a 70 km trail for hikers and cyclists.

column1: This historic city is situated on the San River at the foot of Castle Hill in the Lesser Poland (Małopolska) region. It lies in a wooded
column2: hilly area near the national road number 28
column3: which runs along southern Poland
column4: from Ustrzyki Dolne to Wadowice (340 km or 211 mi away). It is located in the heartland of the Pogórze Bukowskie part of Doły (Pits)
column5: and its average elevation is 300 m (984 ft) above sea level
column6: although there are some hills located within the confines of the city.

column1: Sanok is located on the bank of the river San. The area surrounding mountain range stretches between the Wisłok
column2: Osława and San Rivers in the Salt Mountains (Central Beskidian Piedmont)
column3: in the inland with temperateness climate. The hills of the Bieszczady mountain range are typical for this countryside.  Sanok County is bordered by Krosno County to the west
column4: Brzozów County to the north
column5: Przemyśl County to the north-east and Lesko County to the east. It also borders Slovakia to the south.

column1: After 1339 Galicia–Volhynia was seized by King Casimir III of Poland
column2: who reconfirmed the municipal status of Sanok on 25 April 1366. At that time Sanok became the centre of a new administrative district called Sanok Land
column3: a part of the Ruthenian Voivodeship. Several courts of justice operated in the town
column4: including the municipal and rural courts of lower instance and also the higher instance court for the entire Sanok Land
column5: based on the German town law. Germans settled in the territory of the Kingdom of Poland (territory of present-day Subcarpathian Voivodeship) from the 14th to 16th centuries (see Ostsiedlung)
column6: mostly after the region returned to Polish sphere of influence in 1340
column7: when Casimir III of Poland took the Czerwień towns.

column2: an important trade route went across Sanok connecting the interior of Hungary with Poland through the Łupków Pass. As a result of the first of Partitions of Poland (Treaty of St-Petersburg dated 5 July 1772

column1: The course of the river Dunajec and that of the San
column2: both in West Galicia
column3: marked the two successive stages in the breakthrough battle which initiated the Austro-German offensive of 1915 on the eastern front. An attempt to hold the line of the Wisłok river and the Łupków Pass failed before renewed Austro-German attacks on 8 May 1915. Wisłok Valley was one of the strategically important Carpathian rivers bitterly contested in battles on the Eastern Front of World War I during the winter of 1914–1915.

column2: the Russian army occupied the town from May until July
column3: 1915 and significantly damaged the town. The town was subsequently occupied by troops of the Austro-Hungarian Empire.

column2: Sanok was known as a centre of Ukrainian movement in Galicia
column3: and of cultural heritage of the Lemkos and other Rusyns.

column1: The Jewish population of Sanok may have been almost 30% for many years in the early 20th century.  At the beginning of the Nazi occupation
column2: the Jewish population was around 5000.  With the advent of the Nazis and with anti-semitism in Galicia
column3: most of the Jews were either executed or killed in Nazi death camps or Nazi concentration camps during the Holocaust. Some of the actions against the Jews were assisted by Ukrainian auxiliaries and hundreds of the deaths occurred in Sanok itself. Buildings that had been owned by Jews were taken by the local population.  The local Jewish cemetery still exists. Several hundred Jews are thought to have survived
column4: most of whom fled to the Soviet Union at the beginning of the war. Some of the Jews emigrated to Canada and the United States in the early 1900s with Sanoker Burial Societies spreading throughout New York and other regions where they settled.

column1: In 1943 the foundation of the Waffen-SS Division Galizien took place in heavily Ukrainian-populated Sanok
column2: with many locals volunteering in the ethnic Ukrainian Waffen-SS. Because of material support and assistance provided by the local population to the Ukrainian Insurgent Army
column3: which was waging a battle for Ukrainian separatism against the Polish state
column4: Polish authorities deported the Ukrainian and Lemko population of Sanok and its region to the former eastern territories of Germany attached to Poland after World War II (the so-called Recovered Territories) during Operation Vistula (1946–1947). Some the Lemkos expelled returned to Sanok in 1957-58 and others after 1989.

column1: Sanok contains an open-air museum called a skansen in the Biała Góra district
column2: where examples of architecture from all of the region's main ethnic groups have been moved and carefully reassembled in a skansen evoking everyday rural life in the 19th century.
the south-eastern Poland region that is now Subcarpathia was overrun in pre-Roman times by various tribes
column3: including the Celts (Anarti)

column1: The region subsequently became part of the Great Moravian state. Upon the invasion of the Hungarian tribes into the heart of the Great Moravian Empire around 899
column2: the Lendians of the area declared their allegiance to Hungarian Empire. The region then became a site of contention between Poland
column3: Kievan Rus' and Hungary starting in at least the 9th century.

column1: The first traces of settlement in the area of modern Sanok date back to at least the 9th century. The following century a Slavic fortified town (gord) was created there and initially served as a center of pagan worship. The etymology of the name is unclear
column2: though most scholars derive it from the Celtic river-name San. Certain archaeological excavations performed on the castle hill and on Fajka hill near Sanok-Trepcza
column3: not only confirm the written resources
column4: but date the Sanok stronghold origin to as early as the 9th century. On Fajka hill
column5: where probably the first settlement of Sanok was situated
column6: some remains of an ancient sanctuary and a cemetery were found
column7: as well as numerous decorations and encolpions in Kievan type. Also found were two seals of the Great Kievan Prince Rurik Rostislavich from the second half of the 12th century.

column1: Sanok has a strong industry base - home to Stomil Sanok (established in 1932) and Pass Gummiwerke plants
column2: producers of various rubber and metal-rubber seals
column3: strings and laggings for automotive sector
column4: construction industries and electrical household goods sector
column5: PGNiG and Sanok Bus Car Factory "Autosan" (established in 1832)
column6: a producer of high capacity buses
column7: cabins for the Polish Army and bodies for rail-vehicles. Stomil is next to the main train station in Sanok and Autosan is a 10-minute walk from the station
column8: while the town centre is a 15-minute walk in the other direction.

column1: The town has several public schools and a branch of the Polish High School of Technology. The town also has a football club called Stal Sanok and some other sport clubs (including volleyball
column2: swimming
column3: handball
column4: ice hockey). The Sanok Castle near the centre of the old town houses a museum displaying over 300 fine icons. The Museum of Folk Architecture is one of the biggest open-air museums in Poland and show cases 19th and early 20th century life in this area of Poland.

column2: which has won the Polska Hokej Liga league title twice

column4: in 2010-11 and 2011–12. The local football club is Stal Sanok
column5: which most recently competed in the Polish Third League (4th level)
column6: in the 2013/14 season. The team is currently inactive due to financial reasons.
